pages.tocTitle: MRI Characteristics in Natalizumab-Treated MS patients with Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy
pages.cola:
MRI Characteristics in Natalizumab-Treated MS patients with Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy

One of the adverse effects of natalizumab is the increased risk of the rare but serious condition, progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy(PML). The MRI characteristics in patients with PML after natalizumab treatment are relatively heterogeneous, but guidelines for differentiating MRI findings in PML from inflammatory demyelinating lesions may facilitate early diagnosis of PML. These guidelines were outlined in a recent review.16 In particular, PML patients frequently exhibit large, subcortical, fluid-attenuated inversion recovery hyperintense, T1-hypointense, and diffusion-hyperintense lesions with a sharp border toward the gray matter and an ill-defined border toward the white matter on T2-weighted images.17
pages.page_title: MRI Characteristics in Natalizumab-Treated MS patients with Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy
pages.template:
MRI Characteristics in Natalizumab-Treated MS patients with Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy

One of the adverse effects of natalizumab is the increased risk of the rare but serious condition, progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy(PML). The MRI characteristics in patients with PML after natalizumab treatment are relatively heterogeneous, but guidelines for differentiating MRI findings in PML from inflammatory demyelinating lesions may facilitate early diagnosis of PML. These guidelines were outlined in a recent review.16 In particular, PML patients frequently exhibit large, subcortical, fluid-attenuated inversion recovery hyperintense, T1-hypointense, and diffusion-hyperintense lesions with a sharp border toward the gray matter and an ill-defined border toward the white matter on T2-weighted images.17

pages.cola:
New MS Imaging Technologies

Atrophy Measures

Brain volume decreases in MS patients more rapidly than the normal aging population. It may decrease by 0.49% each year in untreated patients with RRMS, 0.40%/year in CIS, 0.56%/year in primary-progressive MS(PPMS), and 0.64%/year in SPMS, as observed by one group of investigators.18 By comparing serial MRIs performed in accordance with the standardized protocols described previously, it then becomes possible to measure whole-brain atrophy in MS patients over time. This can be measured by calculating the proportion or fraction of brain parenchymal volume divided by the volume within the brain's surface(parenchymal plus cerebrospinal fluid), which appears to be a marker for irreversible neurologic damage in MS. Alternatively, one can estimate the percentage of brain volume change over two consecutive patient scans using SIENA, a software freely available for noncommercial use.19 It is now also possible to measure regional changes of the brain and to evaluate correlations between those changes and clinical outcomes using voxel-based morphometry.20 Reductions in cerebral volume and cortical volume have been shown to correlate with cognitive impairment, for example.21,22
pages.colb:
Additionally, regional thalamic atrophy observed using MRI examinations were recently shown to be associated with the conversion from CIS to CDMS.23 Unfortunately, these atrophy measurement methods have yet to be integrated into routine clinical practice because of lack of standardization, software availability, and lack of reimbursement for postimage acquisition processing.

"Pseudoatrophy"poses a challenge in measuring brain atrophy. Short-term increases in cerebral volume can occur as a result of edema and osmotic and anti-inflammatory effects.24-26 Resolution of this effect, typically during initial immunomodulatory treatment, results in a decrease in brain volume that does not represent true tissue loss(atrophy). The use of advanced magnetic resonance sequences may be a potential means of distinguishing neuroaxonal loss from changes in water content.27 Another challenge is the topographic distribution of volume loss. Atrophy seems greatest in gray matter, especially the basal ganglia and thalamus, and increases at a greater rate in gray matter than in white matter as the disease progresses.27,28
pages.template:
New MS Imaging Technologies

Atrophy Measures

Brain volume decreases in MS patients more rapidly than the normal aging population. It may decrease by 0.49% each year in untreated patients with RRMS, 0.40%/year in CIS, 0.56%/year in primary-progressive MS(PPMS), and 0.64%/year in SPMS, as observed by one group of investigators.18 By comparing serial MRIs performed in accordance with the standardized protocols described previously, it then becomes possible to measure whole-brain atrophy in MS patients over time. This can be measured by calculating the proportion or fraction of brain parenchymal volume divided by the volume within the brain's surface(parenchymal plus cerebrospinal fluid), which appears to be a marker for irreversible neurologic damage in MS. Alternatively, one can estimate the percentage of brain volume change over two consecutive patient scans using SIENA, a software freely available for noncommercial use.19 It is now also possible to measure regional changes of the brain and to evaluate correlations between those changes and clinical outcomes using voxel-based morphometry.20 Reductions in cerebral volume and cortical volume have been shown to correlate with cognitive impairment, for example.21,22

Additionally, regional thalamic atrophy observed using MRI examinations were recently shown to be associated with the conversion from CIS to CDMS.23 Unfortunately, these atrophy measurement methods have yet to be integrated into routine clinical practice because of lack of standardization, software availability, and lack of reimbursement for postimage acquisition processing.

"Pseudoatrophy"poses a challenge in measuring brain atrophy. Short-term increases in cerebral volume can occur as a result of edema and osmotic and anti-inflammatory effects.24-26 Resolution of this effect, typically during initial immunomodulatory treatment, results in a decrease in brain volume that does not represent true tissue loss(atrophy). The use of advanced magnetic resonance sequences may be a potential means of distinguishing neuroaxonal loss from changes in water content.27 Another challenge is the topographic distribution of volume loss. Atrophy seems greatest in gray matter, especially the basal ganglia and thalamus, and increases at a greater rate in gray matter than in white matter as the disease progresses.27,28

pages.cola:
Furthermore, MS gray matter shows less inflammatory cells than white matter, so gray matter volume is less likely to be confounded by pseudoatrophy. However, the best methods of characterizing atrophy in gray matter have yet to be determined.27 When analyzing atrophy, other factors influencing brain volume, such as normal aging effects and comorbid conditions, must also be considered.

Atrophy of the cervical spinal cord has been shown to correlate with the development of disability in MS, and has been used to monitor disease progression and effects of drug therapy.29 The technical challenges of getting accurate and precise spinal cord images have been addressed in studies that have analyzed improved receiving coils, fast imaging, 3D imaging, motion suppression, and cardiac gating.29 A recent study analyzed the utility of measuring whole cervical cord volume, rather than the traditional cross-sectional area approach at level C2/C3, using a semiautomated edge detection technique to create a tissue-boundary map from 3D volumetric scans of the cervical cord.
pages.colb:
With this method, the researchers determined that cervical cord absolute volume was the best metric for defining differences in atrophy between normal control patients and patients with MS, and between different disease subtypes, compared with two normalized cervical cord measures: cervical cord fraction and cervical cord to intracranial volume fraction.29

pages.template:
Furthermore, MS gray matter shows less inflammatory cells than white matter, so gray matter volume is less likely to be confounded by pseudoatrophy. However, the best methods of characterizing atrophy in gray matter have yet to be determined.27 When analyzing atrophy, other factors influencing brain volume, such as normal aging effects and comorbid conditions, must also be considered.

Atrophy of the cervical spinal cord has been shown to correlate with the development of disability in MS, and has been used to monitor disease progression and effects of drug therapy.29 The technical challenges of getting accurate and precise spinal cord images have been addressed in studies that have analyzed improved receiving coils, fast imaging, 3D imaging, motion suppression, and cardiac gating.29 A recent study analyzed the utility of measuring whole cervical cord volume, rather than the traditional cross-sectional area approach at level C2/C3, using a semiautomated edge detection technique to create a tissue-boundary map from 3D volumetric scans of the cervical cord.

With this method, the researchers determined that cervical cord absolute volume was the best metric for defining differences in atrophy between normal control patients and patients with MS, and between different disease subtypes, compared with two normalized cervical cord measures: cervical cord fraction and cervical cord to intracranial volume fraction.29

pages.cola:
Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy

Unlike conventional MRI and other nonconventional MRI methods, proton magnetic resonance spectroscopy(MRS)does not measure signal from water hydrogen protons but quantifies signal from various cellular metabolites(eg, N-acetyl aspartate, choline, creatine, myo-inositol, lactate)located in a selected area of the brain.30,31 The peak height, or resonance intensity, of these metabolites is proportional to the density of the metabolite in the volume of tissue(voxel)being examined.32 Single or multiple voxels, or even the entire brain, can be acquired at once.31 The resonances correlate with specific MS-related pathologic events, such as demyelination, inflammation, gliosis, and axonal/neuronal dysfunction.33 For example, in the adult normal brain, N-acetyl aspartate has the highest resonance intensity and is believed to be a specific marker of axonal/neuronal integrity.33 Therefore, a decrease in N-acetyl aspartate resonance intensity is indicative of neurodegeneration or axonal functional compromise.31 In contrast, a heightened choline resonance intensity often represents breakdown of myelin, remyelination, and inflammation.27
pages.colb:
The concentration of creatine increases as cell density increases, whereas increased myo-inositol indicates glial proliferation and astrogliosis.27 Other metabolites under investigation include glutamate, glutathione, gamma-aminobutyric acid, ascorbic acid, and the macromolecular(background)signal encompassing the macromolecules valine, alanine, leucine, isoleucine, and threonine, which together comprise up to 60% of myelin content.27 The main advantage of MRS is that it can provide specific information about neurodegeneration and tissue repair, even in areas in which no lesions are visible on conventional MRI, and even in early stages of the MS.32

Some multicenter clinical trials have begun incorporating MRS outcome measures, which also require use of a standardized MRS protocol and central analysis of data. Although MRS pulse sequences are readily available on most clinical scanners, precision is necessary during the acquisition of images to ensure accurate comparisons. Controlled trials of standardized protocols and analysis software need to be completed before the usefulness of MRS outcome measures can be determined for monitoring disease progression in the clinic. The use of higher magnet strengths(3T, 7T)should improve the sensitivity and reproducibility of MRS measures.

pages.cola:
Functional MRI

Functional MRI(fMRI)measures changes in blood flow to functioning brain areas. This allows mapping of functional network connections, and changes in those connections, during specific tasks. For example, fMRI has shown that adaptive, compensatory changes in the brain may help preserve cognitive function in MS patients even in the presence of white matter lesions and cortical atrophy.34,35 These changes consist largely of increased activation of some brain areas and recruitment of other areas to expand networks engaged in specific tasks when compared with healthy persons.36,37 fMRI patterns may change over time, even in clinically stable MS patients.37 fMRI shows functional abnormalities in large-scale neuronal networks in MS, which correlate with T2 lesions and disability.38 However, the impact of white matter T2 lesions on increased activation measured by fMRI in the cortex remains largely unknown.
pages.template:
Functional MRI

Functional MRI(fMRI)measures changes in blood flow to functioning brain areas. This allows mapping of functional network connections, and changes in those connections, during specific tasks. For example, fMRI has shown that adaptive, compensatory changes in the brain may help preserve cognitive function in MS patients even in the presence of white matter lesions and cortical atrophy.34,35 These changes consist largely of increased activation of some brain areas and recruitment of other areas to expand networks engaged in specific tasks when compared with healthy persons.36,37 fMRI patterns may change over time, even in clinically stable MS patients.37 fMRI shows functional abnormalities in large-scale neuronal networks in MS, which correlate with T2 lesions and disability.38 However, the impact of white matter T2 lesions on increased activation measured by fMRI in the cortex remains largely unknown.

pages.cola:
Diffusion Imaging

Diffusion imaging measures the random translational motion of water molecules that results from thermal energy. Water molecules diffuse rapidly in the direction of brain neural axons, allowing for visualization of the location and orientation of neural tracts(fiber tracking or tractography). Diffusion tensor imaging(DTI)employs quantitative metrics, such as mean diffusivity and fractional anisotropy. Mean diffusivity is an averaged measure of the apparent diffusion coefficient from the three main orthogonal directions or vectors—an estimated measure of water motion through more or less restricted physical barriers. Fractional anisotropy summarizes the directional dependence of diffusivity(ie, variance or standard deviation of the three main directions or vectors).39 With mean diffusivity and fractional anisotropy, the orientation, size, integrity, and geometry of tissue in white and gray matter can be estimated.9 One study describes the use of DTI to measure the tissue integrity of specific spinal cord tracts, each associated with different clinical functions.40 DTI can also quantify the severity of brain and cervical cord pathology in MS. It has been shown to detect microstructural damage in normal-appearing white matter and deep gray nuclei(thalamus), as well as in focal analysis of cortical lesions.41,42
pages.colb:
Importantly, white matter damage measured with DTI has been found in areas highly relevant for cognition in cognitively impaired patients but not in cognitively preserved patients, thereby supporting the utility of DTI in monitoring cognitive impairment.43 DTI changes along specific pyramidal tracts in MS patients have been shown to be strongly correlated with physical disability as measured by the pyramidal Kurtzke functional system scores.44

Further study is warranted to determine the utility of DTI in clinical practice.42 Another novel application of diffusion MRI, diffusion orientational complexity, a new MRI measure, has been studied as a means of assessing functionally relevant cortical pathology in MS.45

pages.cola:
Magnetization Transfer Imaging

Magnetization transfer imaging(MTI)measures the continuous exchange of magnetization that occurs between protons bound to macromolecules and free water molecules. A quantitative measurement of the concentration of macromolecular protons is called the magnetization transfer ratio(MTR), which is the difference in signal intensity with versus without magnetization transfer. A low brain MTR could indicate damaged myelin and axonal membranes.27 MTI is a sensitive marker of tissue damage in MS, and MTR changes in gray matter of patients with early RRMS or PPMS have been shown to predict future disability.46,47 A recent study of the clinical relevance of changes in gray matter found that gray matter damage, as identified by MTR abnormalities, were predictive of long-term disability in MS.48

Recent developments in MTI include voxel-based approaches, which allow decreases in MTR to be anatomically located and have more recently been used to track demyelination and remyelination in individual MS lesions.49 Atlas-based approaches have been used in longitudinal studies to track MTR changes within T2-visible lesions, thereby enabling the chronologic classification of new, stable, and resolved lesions.
pages.colb:
This could potentially improve correlations with clinical manifestations of MS and enhance monitoring of treatment effect on myelin repair and neuroprotection.27

Susceptibility Weighted, Phase, and T2* Imaging

Susceptibility weighted imaging(SWI)and phase imaging use differences in local magnetic susceptibility between tissues as a new form of contrast that is particularly useful in distinguishing between gray and white matter tissues with heavy iron concentration and venous blood vessels.50 SWI has the potential to visualize lesions not visible on conventional MRI.51,52 Iron deposition, as visualized on SWI and phase imaging, may be a marker of disease progression in the deep gray nuclei and may distinguish MS lesion types.51,53

A new FLAIR 7T MRI technique has been shown to improve differentiation between MS and vascular lesions by combining FLAIR and T2* images.54
pages.template:
Magnetization Transfer Imaging

This could potentially improve correlations with clinical manifestations of MS and enhance monitoring of treatment effect on myelin repair and neuroprotection.27

Susceptibility Weighted, Phase, and T2* Imaging

A new FLAIR 7T MRI technique has been shown to improve differentiation between MS and vascular lesions by combining FLAIR and T2* images.54

pages.cola:
Other New Imaging Techniques

McDonald criteria are based on the use of conventional MRI at 1.5T magnet strength to detect lesions in noncortical brain and spinal tissue.2 Double-inversion recovery imaging—a new MRI sequence in which the signal from the cerebrospinal fluid and white matter is attenuated—facilitates detection of cortical lesions, which are present in more than half of MS patients, and better defines mixed white-and-gray-matter lesions.51,52,55 Results from a postmortem study showed that 3D-double-inversion recovery MRI is a sensitive tool for detection of cortical lesions.56 However, in vivo, phase-sensitive inversion recovery identifies more gray matter lesions than double-inversion recovery. Higher magnet strengths(eg, 3T)increase image resolution, and improve signal-to-noise ratio and T2 contrast, allowing for enhanced detection of both white and gray matter lesions.2,57-60 Studies using 7T magnets have demonstrated improved resolution for lesions within gray matter and at the cortical/subcortical boundary and better revealed microvascular abnormalities and iron deposition in MS.52,57,61,62 7T FLASH-T2 has also been demonstrated to be superior to 3T double-inversion recovery for the detection of cortical lesions.63 Multicontrast 7T MRI is better at imaging grey matter(but not white matter)lesions compared with 3T MRI.64
pages.colb:
A lesion distribution postprocessing mapping approach has been used to appropriately distinguish neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder from RRMS.65

Although very preliminary, positron emission tomography(PET)scan may have utility in MS grey matter imaging: Increased cortical grey matter C11-PK11195 binding on PET scan, thought to be indicative of microglial or astrocyte activation, was associated with increased MS-related disability.66

Conclusion

MRI is an important tool for diagnosis and monitoring of MS patients. However, use of a standardized protocol is necessary when comparing serial images. Prospective longitudinal data are needed to determine how MRI-based evidence of disease should influence treatment decisions. Newer MRI technologies have the potential to enhance estimation of MS prognosis, but there are limitations to the use of these technologies due to measurement and interpretation difficulties and standardization issues, and they are sometimes used inappropriately. Guidelines need to be developed to facilitate the extension of advanced MRI techniques to clinical care of MS patients.
pages.template:
Other New Imaging Techniques

McDonald criteria are based on the use of conventional MRI at 1.5T magnet strength to detect lesions in noncortical brain and spinal tissue.2 Double-inversion recovery imaging—a new MRI sequence in which the signal from the cerebrospinal fluid and white matter is attenuated—facilitates detection of cortical lesions, which are present in more than half of MS patients, and better defines mixed white-and-gray-matter lesions.51,52,55 Results from a postmortem study showed that 3D-double-inversion recovery MRI is a sensitive tool for detection of cortical lesions.56 However, in vivo, phase-sensitive inversion recovery identifies more gray matter lesions than double-inversion recovery. Higher magnet strengths(eg, 3T)increase image resolution, and improve signal-to-noise ratio and T2 contrast, allowing for enhanced detection of both white and gray matter lesions.2,57-60 Studies using 7T magnets have demonstrated improved resolution for lesions within gray matter and at the cortical/subcortical boundary and better revealed microvascular abnormalities and iron deposition in MS.52,57,61,62 7T FLASH-T2 has also been demonstrated to be superior to 3T double-inversion recovery for the detection of cortical lesions.63 Multicontrast 7T MRI is better at imaging grey matter(but not white matter)lesions compared with 3T MRI.64

A lesion distribution postprocessing mapping approach has been used to appropriately distinguish neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder from RRMS.65

Although very preliminary, positron emission tomography(PET)scan may have utility in MS grey matter imaging: Increased cortical grey matter C11-PK11195 binding on PET scan, thought to be indicative of microglial or astrocyte activation, was associated with increased MS-related disability.66

Conclusion

MRI is an important tool for diagnosis and monitoring of MS patients. However, use of a standardized protocol is necessary when comparing serial images. Prospective longitudinal data are needed to determine how MRI-based evidence of disease should influence treatment decisions. Newer MRI technologies have the potential to enhance estimation of MS prognosis, but there are limitations to the use of these technologies due to measurement and interpretation difficulties and standardization issues, and they are sometimes used inappropriately. Guidelines need to be developed to facilitate the extension of advanced MRI techniques to clinical care of MS patients.

questions.qtext: On conventional MRI, which of the following are the two best measures of axonal loss?
questions.qexplanation: The best measures of axonal loss on conventional MRI are volume of T1 hypointensities(black holes)and brain atrophy. Conventional MRI T2-weighted images can detect inflammation, edema, demyelination, and axonal loss;however, MRI does not differentiate between irreversible and reversible damage and is unable to detect axonal injury in normal-appearing brain tissue. Volume of "black holes"(areas of T1 hypointensity)on conventional MRI is thought to be a marker for axonal loss, but correlation with clinical outcomes remains uncertain. White matter is composed largely of axons and myelin;therefore, progressive brain atrophy likely represents demyelination and axonal loss. Whole-brain atrophy correlates better with EDSS and cognitive dysfunction than does white matter T2 lesion load on conventional MRI.

answers.atext: Volume of T1 hypointense areas and brain atrophy
Volume of T2 and T1 enhancing lesions
Number of T2 lesions and T1 hypointense areas
Brain atrophy and volume of T2 lesions

questions.qtext: Optical coherence tomography(OCT)can be used in MS to quantify:
questions.qexplanation: OCT is one of several paraclinical measures of the optic nerve that can be used to measure thickness of the retinal nerve fiber layer(RNFL). The RNFL is the inner-most layer of the retina and consists of unmyelinated axons. Therefore, change in thickness of the RNFL is a measure of axonal degeneration. Pathologic events affecting the optic nerve are similar to those in acute lesions in other locations of the CNS.

answers.atext: The extent of demyelination of the retinal nerve
The extent of remyelination of the retinal nerve
Axonal loss in the optic nerve

questions.qtext: Which of the following may be a CSF biomarker that indicates neuronal or axonal damage?
questions.qexplanation: Tau protein is a possible CSF biomarker of neuronal or axonal damage. Other such markers may include N-acetyl aspartic acid, neuron-specific enolase, and neurofilaments. Myelin basic protein is a possible marker for demyelination. Nerve growth factor and insulin-like growth factor-1 are possible markers of remyelination.

questions.qtext: Clinical trials have shown that progression of brain atrophy is slowed by treatment with:
questions.qexplanation: Recent clinical trials have demonstrated that progression of brain atrophy is slowed in patients taking interferon, glatiramer acetate, natalizumab, or fingolimod.

questions.qtext: Which of the following statements is true regarding in vitro activity of investigational MS therapies?
questions.qexplanation: Laquinimod and alemtuzumab increase BDNF expression. In vitro, laquinimod increased microglia and macrophage expression of BDNF by three-fold. Laquinimod also increased BDNF in EAE. Alemtuzumab increased T-cell expression of BDNF in peripheral blood mononuclear cell cultures simulated with myelin basic protein. Laquinimod neither enhanced nor reduced oligodendrocyte progenitor cell viability and proliferation in vitro. Dimethyl fumarate downregulated proinflammatory mediators(iNOS, TNF-alpha, interleukin[IL]-1 beta, IL-6)in vitro.

answers.atext: Laquinimod increases oligodendrocyte progenitor cell proliferation
Dimethyl fumarate increases expression of iNOS and TNF-alpha

questions.qtext: The STEMS Consensus Group supports initiation of proof-of-principle trials of mesenchymal stem cells and neural stem/precursor cells:
questions.qexplanation: The STEMS Consensus Group supports initiation of phase I trials of single intrathecal administration of NPCs or MSCs. The STEMS Consensus Group recommended that stem cell therapy proof-of-principle studies be restricted to patients with either SPMS who are not responding to conventional therapies or primary progressive MS with ongoing CNS inflammation.

answers.atext: In a series of three administrations

questions.qtext: Was the activity effective in meeting the identified learning objective(s)?

subquestions.stext: Evaluate methods of measuring neuroprotective activity of therapeutic agents in multiple sclerosis(MS)in order to recognize their strengths and limitations.
Assess the neuroprotective potential of current and emerging MS therapies, novel agents, and stem cell therapy based on available in vitro, in vivo, and clinical data.

pages.cola:
Chapter 5.2: Neuroprotection and Neuroregeneration in Multiple Sclerosis

Editors-in-Chief: Bruce A. Cohen, MD, and Patricia K. Coyle, MD
Contributing Editor: Michael K. Racke, MD
Medical Writer, Original manuscript: Lauren Cerruto
Medical Writer, Updates to manuscript: Cherie Koch

 

Introduction

Trials of multiple sclerosis(MS)therapies have traditionally focused on clinical outcomes, such as relapse rates and disability progression;however, improvement in imaging tools is increasingly allowing for consideration of whether MS therapeutics are also neuroprotective. The "Holy Grail"of MS treatment would be a therapy that not only protects neurons from further demyelination and axonal loss, but also allows for remyelination, neuroregeneration, and restoration of lost function.

pages.template:
Chapter 5.2: Neuroprotection and Neuroregeneration in Multiple Sclerosis

Editors-in-Chief: Bruce A. Cohen, MD, and Patricia K. Coyle, MD
Contributing Editor: Michael K. Racke, MD
Medical Writer, Original manuscript: Lauren Cerruto
Medical Writer, Updates to manuscript: Cherie Koch

 

Introduction

Trials of multiple sclerosis(MS)therapies have traditionally focused on clinical outcomes, such as relapse rates and disability progression;however, improvement in imaging tools is increasingly allowing for consideration of whether MS therapeutics are also neuroprotective. The "Holy Grail"of MS treatment would be a therapy that not only protects neurons from further demyelination and axonal loss, but also allows for remyelination, neuroregeneration, and restoration of lost function.

pages.tocTitle: Endogenous Mechanisms of Neuroprotection and Neuroregeneration(A)
pages.cola:
This chapter looks at modern definitions and means of assessing neuroprotection and neurodegeneration, and available data on the neuroprotective potential of current and emerging treatment approaches.

Endogenous Mechanisms of Neuroprotection and Neuroregeneration

The natural immune response in MS can be both deleterious and neuroprotective. Autoreactive T-cells are thought to be the main contributor to chronic inflammation, demyelination, and axonal loss.1 They may also aid in neuroprotection, but this is controversial.1 CD8+T-cells predominate in MS lesions and can be found in direct contact with demyelinated axons.2,3 In contrast, regulatory T-cells and a subset of CD8+T-cells suppress inflammation.4-6 CD4+T-cells may be inflammatory or neuroprotective depending on which cytokines and neurotrophins they secrete.3 Some autoreactive T-cells release brain-derived neurotrophic factor(BDNF). BDNF is thought to have neuroprotective effects, but also reduces the susceptibility of activated T-cells to apoptosis, thereby prolonging their survival.1
pages.colb:
Additional sources of neuronal injury include:

  • Other immune cells(eg, activated macrophages and microglia, B-cell–produced antibodies, complement)2,3,7
  • Excess glutamate activity8
  • Overproduction of nitric oxide2
  • Free radicals7
  • Insufficient trophic support from myelin and oligodendrocytes2
  • Disrupted axonal repair mechanisms2
  • Calcium excitotoxicity2,7
  • Matrix metalloproteinase-9 and other proteinases7
  • Demyelination7
  • Failure of oligodendrocyte precursor cells to proliferate and differentiate9
pages.page_title: Endogenous Mechanisms of Neuroprotection and Neuroregeneration(A)
pages.template:
This chapter looks at modern definitions and means of assessing neuroprotection and neurodegeneration, and available data on the neuroprotective potential of current and emerging treatment approaches.

Endogenous Mechanisms of Neuroprotection and Neuroregeneration

The natural immune response in MS can be both deleterious and neuroprotective. Autoreactive T-cells are thought to be the main contributor to chronic inflammation, demyelination, and axonal loss.1 They may also aid in neuroprotection, but this is controversial.1 CD8+T-cells predominate in MS lesions and can be found in direct contact with demyelinated axons.2,3 In contrast, regulatory T-cells and a subset of CD8+T-cells suppress inflammation.4-6 CD4+T-cells may be inflammatory or neuroprotective depending on which cytokines and neurotrophins they secrete.3 Some autoreactive T-cells release brain-derived neurotrophic factor(BDNF). BDNF is thought to have neuroprotective effects, but also reduces the susceptibility of activated T-cells to apoptosis, thereby prolonging their survival.1

Additional sources of neuronal injury include:

  • Other immune cells(eg, activated macrophages and microglia, B-cell–produced antibodies, complement)2,3,7
  • Excess glutamate activity8
  • Overproduction of nitric oxide2
  • Free radicals7
  • Insufficient trophic support from myelin and oligodendrocytes2
  • Disrupted axonal repair mechanisms2
  • Calcium excitotoxicity2,7
  • Matrix metalloproteinase-9 and other proteinases7
  • Demyelination7
  • Failure of oligodendrocyte precursor cells to proliferate and differentiate9

pages.tocTitle: Endogenous Mechanisms of Neuroprotection and Neuroregeneration(B)
pages.cola:
In addition to neuronal injury, the immune system may contribute to neuroprotection in MS. As noted previously, T-cells have some neuroprotective effects. In addition, regulatory B-cells produce anti-inflammatory cytokines, and some autoantibodies promote remyelination.4,10 Inflammation itself may be protective: Animal studies indicate that oligodendrocyte progenitor cells(OPCs)engage in remyelination only in the presence of inflammation.11,12 Activated by inflammation, astrocytes migrate to and wrap around sites of injury to provide protection against continued damage.3 Astrocytes also promote T-cell apoptosis and induce regulatory T-cells.3 Animal studies have also shown that the addition of Klotho protein to oligodendrocytes enhances maturation of OPCs and production of healthy myelin.13

Neurons regulate the expression of major histocompatibility complex class I and II on nearby glia, produce cytokines, promote T-cell apoptosis, and induce regulatory T-cells.3 However, remyelination is inhibited by the presence of myelin debris, interferon-gamma, fibroblast growth factor 2, and CXCR2.14-17
pages.colb: Axonal loss occurs in acute inflammatory lesions from disease onset, sometimes even preceding demyelination.2,3 Up to a certain threshold, compensatory mechanisms(eg, cortical plasticity)allow for functional recovery.2,3 Brain plasticity reserve in the form of long-term synaptic potentiation is critical to minimize the effects of neuronal loss in MS, and enhanced platelet-derived growth factor may be a treatment option in the progressive phases of MS.18 Transition from relapsing-remitting MS(RRMS)to secondary-progressive MS(SPMS)occurs when axonal loss has exceeded that threshold, despite endogenous neuroprotective activity.2
pages.page_title: Endogenous Mechanisms of Neuroprotection and Neuroregeneration(B)
pages.template:
In addition to neuronal injury, the immune system may contribute to neuroprotection in MS. As noted previously, T-cells have some neuroprotective effects. In addition, regulatory B-cells produce anti-inflammatory cytokines, and some autoantibodies promote remyelination.4,10 Inflammation itself may be protective: Animal studies indicate that oligodendrocyte progenitor cells(OPCs)engage in remyelination only in the presence of inflammation.11,12 Activated by inflammation, astrocytes migrate to and wrap around sites of injury to provide protection against continued damage.3 Astrocytes also promote T-cell apoptosis and induce regulatory T-cells.3 Animal studies have also shown that the addition of Klotho protein to oligodendrocytes enhances maturation of OPCs and production of healthy myelin.13

Neurons regulate the expression of major histocompatibility complex class I and II on nearby glia, produce cytokines, promote T-cell apoptosis, and induce regulatory T-cells.3 However, remyelination is inhibited by the presence of myelin debris, interferon-gamma, fibroblast growth factor 2, and CXCR2.14-17

Axonal loss occurs in acute inflammatory lesions from disease onset, sometimes even preceding demyelination.2,3 Up to a certain threshold, compensatory mechanisms(eg, cortical plasticity)allow for functional recovery.2,3 Brain plasticity reserve in the form of long-term synaptic potentiation is critical to minimize the effects of neuronal loss in MS, and enhanced platelet-derived growth factor may be a treatment option in the progressive phases of MS.18 Transition from relapsing-remitting MS(RRMS)to secondary-progressive MS(SPMS)occurs when axonal loss has exceeded that threshold, despite endogenous neuroprotective activity.2

pages.tocTitle: Defining "Neuroprotective Therapy" in MS / Methods of Evaluating Neuroprotection(A)
pages.cola:
Defining "Neuroprotective Therapy"in MS

There is no standardized definition of neuroprotection in MS. In a strict sense, the term is used to refer to direct effects on neurons that prevent apoptosis(primary neuroprotection). However, a broader definition could include any effects, even if indirect, that lead to protection of myelin, axons, and neurons(secondary neuroprotection).19 Secondary neuroprotection might include reduction of inflammation in the central nervous system(CNS), for example.

Neuroregeneration is sometimes used to refer to remyelination;however, some experts believe this term should be limited to restoration of damaged/lost axons. A severed axon would have to sprout and reconnect with its target to meet these more stringent criteria for neuroregeneration.
pages.colb:
Methods of Evaluating Neuroprotection

As noted by van der Walt et al, "The absence of reliable, valid and responsive markers of axonal integrity in MS is the main stumbling block limiting the effective testing of neuroprotective therapies."2

Animal Models. Experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis(EAE), which comprises various animal models of MS, allows examination of the direct effects of a treatment on axons and neurons.2 However, although EAE shares many overlapping features with MS, it cannot be assumed to entirely replicate human disease, given differences in the disease course as well as differences between human and murine immune systems.2 For example, administration of interferon-gamma or an inhibitor of tumor necrosis factor-alpha is neuroprotective in EAE but exacerbates MS in humans.3
pages.page_title: Defining "Neuroprotective Therapy" in MS / Methods of Evaluating Neuroprotection(A)
pages.template:
Defining "Neuroprotective Therapy"in MS

There is no standardized definition of neuroprotection in MS. In a strict sense, the term is used to refer to direct effects on neurons that prevent apoptosis(primary neuroprotection). However, a broader definition could include any effects, even if indirect, that lead to protection of myelin, axons, and neurons(secondary neuroprotection).19 Secondary neuroprotection might include reduction of inflammation in the central nervous system(CNS), for example.

Neuroregeneration is sometimes used to refer to remyelination;however, some experts believe this term should be limited to restoration of damaged/lost axons. A severed axon would have to sprout and reconnect with its target to meet these more stringent criteria for neuroregeneration.

Methods of Evaluating Neuroprotection

As noted by van der Walt et al, "The absence of reliable, valid and responsive markers of axonal integrity in MS is the main stumbling block limiting the effective testing of neuroprotective therapies."2

Animal Models. Experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis(EAE), which comprises various animal models of MS, allows examination of the direct effects of a treatment on axons and neurons.2 However, although EAE shares many overlapping features with MS, it cannot be assumed to entirely replicate human disease, given differences in the disease course as well as differences between human and murine immune systems.2 For example, administration of interferon-gamma or an inhibitor of tumor necrosis factor-alpha is neuroprotective in EAE but exacerbates MS in humans.3

pages.cola:
Conventional MRI. Conventional MRI T2-weighted images can detect inflammation, edema, demyelination, and axonal loss;however, MRI does not differentiate between irreversible and reversible damage and is unable to detect axonal injury in normal-appearing brain tissue.20 Therefore, standard MRI measures correlate only modestly with clinical disability and measures of disease activity.20

Recently, other potential markers for axonal loss on conventional MRI have been identified. Volume of "black holes"(areas of T1 hypointensity)on conventional MRI is thought to be a marker for axonal loss,2 but correlation with clinical outcomes remains uncertain.2,21 By comparing a series of MRIs with the aid of programs like SIENA, it is possible to measure brain atrophy in MS. White matter is composed largely of axons and myelin;therefore, progressive atrophy likely represents demyelination and axonal loss.20 Whole-brain atrophy correlates better with Expanded Disability Status Scale and cognitive dysfunction than does white matter T2 lesion load on conventional MRI.22 Atrophy leads to only small changes in brain volume(about 0.5%–1% per year), so measurement requires precision and sophisticated computations.23
pages.colb: Newer Imaging Techniques. Magnetization transfer imaging, proton magnetic resonance spectroscopy, and diffusion tensor imaging can provide more information about demyelination and axonal loss than conventional imaging.20,22 Magnetization transfer imaging can also provide information about remyelination and changes in white matter that appear normal on conventional MRI.20 MRI performed at higher magnet strength is another promising tool for visualizing remyelination.24 Along with measures of brain atrophy, these and other newer imaging techniques are described in detail in Chapter 5.1. Positron emission tomography with radiolabeled 1,4-bis(p-aminostyryl)-2-methoxy benzene, a Congo red derivative that binds to myelin, can also be used to visualize demyelination and remyelination.25 Many of these newer imaging techniques are limited to the research setting and are not yet available clinically.
pages.template:
Conventional MRI. Conventional MRI T2-weighted images can detect inflammation, edema, demyelination, and axonal loss;however, MRI does not differentiate between irreversible and reversible damage and is unable to detect axonal injury in normal-appearing brain tissue.20 Therefore, standard MRI measures correlate only modestly with clinical disability and measures of disease activity.20

Recently, other potential markers for axonal loss on conventional MRI have been identified. Volume of "black holes"(areas of T1 hypointensity)on conventional MRI is thought to be a marker for axonal loss,2 but correlation with clinical outcomes remains uncertain.2,21 By comparing a series of MRIs with the aid of programs like SIENA, it is possible to measure brain atrophy in MS. White matter is composed largely of axons and myelin;therefore, progressive atrophy likely represents demyelination and axonal loss.20 Whole-brain atrophy correlates better with Expanded Disability Status Scale and cognitive dysfunction than does white matter T2 lesion load on conventional MRI.22 Atrophy leads to only small changes in brain volume(about 0.5%–1% per year), so measurement requires precision and sophisticated computations.23

Newer Imaging Techniques. Magnetization transfer imaging, proton magnetic resonance spectroscopy, and diffusion tensor imaging can provide more information about demyelination and axonal loss than conventional imaging.20,22 Magnetization transfer imaging can also provide information about remyelination and changes in white matter that appear normal on conventional MRI.20 MRI performed at higher magnet strength is another promising tool for visualizing remyelination.24 Along with measures of brain atrophy, these and other newer imaging techniques are described in detail in Chapter 5.1. Positron emission tomography with radiolabeled 1,4-bis(p-aminostyryl)-2-methoxy benzene, a Congo red derivative that binds to myelin, can also be used to visualize demyelination and remyelination.25 Many of these newer imaging techniques are limited to the research setting and are not yet available clinically.

pages.cola: Paraclinical Evaluations of the Optic Nerve. Optic neuritis, a common clinical event in MS, is attributable to localized inflammatory demyelination of the optic nerve.2 Axonal loss in the optic nerve can lead to permanent blindness.2 Pathologic events affecting the optic nerve are similar to those in acute lesions in other locations of the CNS.2 Studies of the optic nerve therefore provide an opportunity for quantitative assessment of axonal degeneration in MS.2
pages.colb:
Quantitative paraclinical measures of the optic nerve include optic nerve MRI, Heidelberg retinal tomography, laser polarimetry, optical coherence tomography, measures of papillary light reflexes, and multifocal visual evoked potentials.2,26 Heidelberg retinal tomography, scanning laser polarimetry, and optical coherence tomography quantify thickness of the retinal nerve fiber layer(RNFL), the inner-most layer of the retina consisting of isolated unmyelinated axons.26 Decreased RNFL thickness represents axonal loss.26 On multifocal visual evoked potentials, decreased amplitude corresponds to axonal loss.27

Other biomarkers. Cerebrospinal fluid(CSF)markers of demyelination(eg, myelin basic protein, antimyelin autoantibodies, nitric oxide degradation products)or remyelination(eg, BDNF, nerve growth factor, neurotrophin 3)represent promising surrogate markers.28 Other CSF biomarkers may be indicators of neuronal or axonal damage(eg, tau protein, N-acetyl aspartic acid, neuron-specific enolase, and neurofilaments).28,29 Insulin-like growth factor 1(IGF-1)contributes to remyelination, but its binding protein, IGF-BP-3, may reduce its bioavailability, so there is also interest in IGF-1 and IGF-BP-3 as serum biomarkers.30,31
pages.template:
Paraclinical Evaluations of the Optic Nerve. Optic neuritis, a common clinical event in MS, is attributable to localized inflammatory demyelination of the optic nerve.2 Axonal loss in the optic nerve can lead to permanent blindness.2 Pathologic events affecting the optic nerve are similar to those in acute lesions in other locations of the CNS.2 Studies of the optic nerve therefore provide an opportunity for quantitative assessment of axonal degeneration in MS.2

Quantitative paraclinical measures of the optic nerve include optic nerve MRI, Heidelberg retinal tomography, laser polarimetry, optical coherence tomography, measures of papillary light reflexes, and multifocal visual evoked potentials.2,26 Heidelberg retinal tomography, scanning laser polarimetry, and optical coherence tomography quantify thickness of the retinal nerve fiber layer(RNFL), the inner-most layer of the retina consisting of isolated unmyelinated axons.26 Decreased RNFL thickness represents axonal loss.26 On multifocal visual evoked potentials, decreased amplitude corresponds to axonal loss.27

Other biomarkers. Cerebrospinal fluid(CSF)markers of demyelination(eg, myelin basic protein, antimyelin autoantibodies, nitric oxide degradation products)or remyelination(eg, BDNF, nerve growth factor, neurotrophin 3)represent promising surrogate markers.28 Other CSF biomarkers may be indicators of neuronal or axonal damage(eg, tau protein, N-acetyl aspartic acid, neuron-specific enolase, and neurofilaments).28,29 Insulin-like growth factor 1(IGF-1)contributes to remyelination, but its binding protein, IGF-BP-3, may reduce its bioavailability, so there is also interest in IGF-1 and IGF-BP-3 as serum biomarkers.30,31

pages.tocTitle: Current and Emerging Therapies: Evidence of Neuroprotection?(A)
pages.cola: In animal models of EAE, it has been observed that osteopontin expression levels correlate with disease severity in both acute and remitting forms, and recently, Szalardy and colleagues33 observed that elevated CSF osteopontin levels correlated with disease severity in patients with various different forms of MS.32,33 These results suggest that osteopontin could serve as a protein biomarker of clinical severity in MS.33 Validation of these biomarkers in large population trials and standardized assays are needed.30
pages.colb:
Current and Emerging Therapies: Evidence of Neuroprotection?

No treatment is FDA approved to provide neuroprotection in MS. Available disease-modifying therapies have effects on the systemic immune response that at least indirectly are likely to protect against inflammation-induced damage in the CNS, and emerging evidence, described below, suggests that many may also have more direct benefits.2 However, it is unlikely that any available therapies have the ability to alter established axonal degeneration(ie, produce neuroregeneration), as evidenced by their lack of efficacy in SPMS.2

Interferon Beta

Data in vitro suggest that interferon beta prevents astrocyte and neuronal progenitor cell apoptosis and inhibits oligodendrocyte differentiation in the presence of astrocytes and microglia.34-36
pages.page_title: Current and Emerging Therapies: Evidence of Neuroprotection?(A)
pages.template:
In animal models of EAE, it has been observed that osteopontin expression levels correlate with disease severity in both acute and remitting forms, and recently, Szalardy and colleagues33 observed that elevated CSF osteopontin levels correlated with disease severity in patients with various different forms of MS.32,33 These results suggest that osteopontin could serve as a protein biomarker of clinical severity in MS.33 Validation of these biomarkers in large population trials and standardized assays are needed.30

 

Current and Emerging Therapies: Evidence of Neuroprotection?

No treatment is FDA approved to provide neuroprotection in MS. Available disease-modifying therapies have effects on the systemic immune response that at least indirectly are likely to protect against inflammation-induced damage in the CNS, and emerging evidence, described below, suggests that many may also have more direct benefits.2 However, it is unlikely that any available therapies have the ability to alter established axonal degeneration(ie, produce neuroregeneration), as evidenced by their lack of efficacy in SPMS.2

Interferon Beta

Data in vitro suggest that interferon beta prevents astrocyte and neuronal progenitor cell apoptosis and inhibits oligodendrocyte differentiation in the presence of astrocytes and microglia.34-36

pages.tocTitle: Current and Emerging Therapies: Evidence of Neuroprotection?(B)
pages.cola:
Interferon beta may reduce progression of brain atrophy. A post hoc analysis in a subgroup of 140 participants from a placebo-controlled trial found that change in brain parenchymal fraction was less during the second year of treatment with interferon beta-1a than in placebo-treated MS patients(-0.233 versus-0.521;P=.03, representing a 55% reduction in rate of brain atrophy).37 Data from another prospective placebo-controlled trial of interferon beta-1a 22 micrograms subcutaneously three times weekly showed less change in brain volume over the 2-year study period in the interferon group compared with controls(-1.18% versus-1.68% respectively;P=.0031).38

Glatiramer Acetate

Glatiramer acetate promotes expression of neurotrophic growth factors, such as BDNF1 and IGF-1 in vitro.1,39 Glatiramer acetate also induces a Th1 to Th2 shift and generates regulatory CD8+T-cells.7,39,40
pages.colb: In EAE, glatiramer acetate increased expression of BDNF by T-cells, astrocytes, neurons, and neuronal progenitor cells and downregulated expression of B-cell Toll-like receptor 9.41,42 Glatiramer acetate also reduced demyelination, preserved axons and motor neurons, increased remyelinating fibers, and improved the integrity of damaged tissue compared with untreated mice.43,44 Other in vivo data show that antibodies to glatiramer acetate may play a role in remyelination of spinal cord axons.45 There is also evidence that glatiramer acetate increases the number and survival of OPCs in the spinal cord.39,44 In another murine model, untreated mice exhibited excessive glutamate-mediated spontaneous excitatory postsynaptic currents, whereas those exposed to glatiramer acetate did not.46 In a rat EAE model, glatiramer acetate protected retinal ganglion cells as measured via visual evoked potentials and electroretinograms.47

pages.template:

Glatiramer Acetate

Glatiramer acetate promotes expression of neurotrophic growth factors, such as BDNF1 and IGF-1 in vitro.1,39 Glatiramer acetate also induces a Th1 to Th2 shift and generates regulatory CD8+T-cells.7,39,40

In EAE, glatiramer acetate increased expression of BDNF by T-cells, astrocytes, neurons, and neuronal progenitor cells and downregulated expression of B-cell Toll-like receptor 9.41,42 Glatiramer acetate also reduced demyelination, preserved axons and motor neurons, increased remyelinating fibers, and improved the integrity of damaged tissue compared with untreated mice.43,44 Other in vivo data show that antibodies to glatiramer acetate may play a role in remyelination of spinal cord axons.45 There is also evidence that glatiramer acetate increases the number and survival of OPCs in the spinal cord.39,44 In another murine model, untreated mice exhibited excessive glutamate-mediated spontaneous excitatory postsynaptic currents, whereas those exposed to glatiramer acetate did not.46 In a rat EAE model, glatiramer acetate protected retinal ganglion cells as measured via visual evoked potentials and electroretinograms.47

pages.tocTitle: Current and Emerging Therapies: Evidence of Neuroprotection?(C)
pages.cola:
It has also been shown to increase myelinated axons and improve callosal conduction of both myelinated and demyelinated axons in EAE.48 Glatiramer acetate has also been shown to provide secondary neuroprotection against glutamate toxicity in EAE by decreasing the activation of microglial cells and the expression of tumor necrosis factor alpha.49

In the small-scale PreCISe phase III study(N=34), patients with clinically isolated syndrome who were treated with glatiramer acetate had improved brain neuroaxonal integrity compared with placebo, as evidenced by increased N-acetylaspartate to creatine ratios(measured using magnetic resonance spectroscopy).50 In a randomized placebo-controlled clinical trial of glatiramer acetate, 239 patients with 1722 new lesions were followed up for a mean of 5.6 months.51 The proportion of lesions classified as black holes was lower in the glatiramer acetate arm at all time points, and the difference was statistically significant 7 months after lesion appearance(Figure 1).51 In other clinical trials, glatiramer acetate reduced brain atrophy and facilitated axonal metabolic recovery measured on magnetic resonance spectroscopy.52-54
pages.colb:
Explore Figure 1: Proportion of New Lesions Evolving into Black Holes on Follow-Up MRI51

Comparisons of Glatiramer Acetate and Interferon Beta. Several clinical trials directly compared glatiramer acetate and interferon beta with inconsistent results. Data from monthly 3-Tesla MRI scans in the BECOME clinical trial showed that interferon beta-1b significantly reduced the proportion of new enhancing lesions that converted to black holes(9.8%)compared with glatiramer acetate(15.2%;P=.02).55 In the BEYOND trial, there were no differences between interferon beta-1b 250 or 500 micrograms subcutaneously every other day or glatiramer acetate 20 mg/day with regard to volume of black holes or normalized brain volume.56

In the small-scale PreCISe phase III study(N=34), patients with clinically isolated syndrome who were treated with glatiramer acetate had improved brain neuroaxonal integrity compared with placebo, as evidenced by increased N-acetylaspartate to creatine ratios(measured using magnetic resonance spectroscopy).50 In a randomized placebo-controlled clinical trial of glatiramer acetate, 239 patients with 1722 new lesions were followed up for a mean of 5.6 months.51 The proportion of lesions classified as black holes was lower in the glatiramer acetate arm at all time points, and the difference was statistically significant 7 months after lesion appearance(Figure 1).51 In other clinical trials, glatiramer acetate reduced brain atrophy and facilitated axonal metabolic recovery measured on magnetic resonance spectroscopy.52-54

Comparisons of Glatiramer Acetate and Interferon Beta. Several clinical trials directly compared glatiramer acetate and interferon beta with inconsistent results. Data from monthly 3-Tesla MRI scans in the BECOME clinical trial showed that interferon beta-1b significantly reduced the proportion of new enhancing lesions that converted to black holes(9.8%)compared with glatiramer acetate(15.2%;P=.02).55 In the BEYOND trial, there were no differences between interferon beta-1b 250 or 500 micrograms subcutaneously every other day or glatiramer acetate 20 mg/day with regard to volume of black holes or normalized brain volume.56

pages.tocTitle: Current and Emerging Therapies: Evidence of Neuroprotection?(D)
pages.cola:
In the REGARD study, there were no differences in number of new black holes between the interferon and glatiramer acetate arms, but glatiramer acetate was significantly more effective at slowing the progression of brain atrophy.57 In a 5-year brain MRI study, there was less progression of brain atrophy with glatiramer acetate versus interferon.58 In the CombiRx study, significantly lower relapse rates were observed with the combination of glatiramer acetate plus interferon beta-1a and with glatiramer acetate alone compared with interferon beta-1a alone;however, there was no difference between treatment groups in disability progression.59 The combination of glatiramer acetate and interferon beta-1a was superior to either agent alone in reducing the number of new lesions on MRI.59

Natalizumab

Natalizumab prevents T-cells from entering the CNS by binding to alpha-4 integrins, including alpha-4 beta-1, which are necessary for T-cell infiltration of the CNS.60 Thus, natalizumab may indirectly protect neurons from T-cell mediated demyelination and axonal damage.
pages.colb:
In the AFFIRM clinical trial, there was a 76% reduction in new T1 hypointense lesions at 2 years(mean 4.6 with placebo versus 1.1 with natalizumab;P <.001).61 Volume of those lesions decreased by 23.5% with natalizumab versus 1.5% with placebo(P <.001).61 During the second year of treatment, progression of brain atrophy was significantly less in the natalizumab arm than in the controls(brain parenchymal fraction-0.24% versus-0.43% respectively;P=.004).61

Zivadinov et al62 enrolled 103 patients with either RRMS or SPMS and 22 age-and gender-matched healthy controls. MS patients were treated with natalizumab monotherapy or interferon beta-1a with or without pulsed intravenous(IV)methylprednisolone. The natalizumab group had higher magnetization transfer ratio(MTR)volume in normal-appearing brain tissue compared with interferon-treated patients or healthy controls at 1 and 2 years of therapy.

pages.template:
In the REGARD study, there were no differences in number of new black holes between the interferon and glatiramer acetate arms, but glatiramer acetate was significantly more effective at slowing the progression of brain atrophy.57 In a 5-year brain MRI study, there was less progression of brain atrophy with glatiramer acetate versus interferon.58 In the CombiRx study, significantly lower relapse rates were observed with the combination of glatiramer acetate plus interferon beta-1a and with glatiramer acetate alone compared with interferon beta-1a alone;however, there was no difference between treatment groups in disability progression.59 The combination of glatiramer acetate and interferon beta-1a was superior to either agent alone in reducing the number of new lesions on MRI.59

Natalizumab prevents T-cells from entering the CNS by binding to alpha-4 integrins, including alpha-4 beta-1, which are necessary for T-cell infiltration of the CNS.60 Thus, natalizumab may indirectly protect neurons from T-cell mediated demyelination and axonal damage.

In the AFFIRM clinical trial, there was a 76% reduction in new T1 hypointense lesions at 2 years(mean 4.6 with placebo versus 1.1 with natalizumab;P <.001).61 Volume of those lesions decreased by 23.5% with natalizumab versus 1.5% with placebo(P <.001).61 During the second year of treatment, progression of brain atrophy was significantly less in the natalizumab arm than in the controls(brain parenchymal fraction-0.24% versus-0.43% respectively;P=.004).61

Zivadinov et al62 enrolled 103 patients with either RRMS or SPMS and 22 age-and gender-matched healthy controls. MS patients were treated with natalizumab monotherapy or interferon beta-1a with or without pulsed intravenous(IV)methylprednisolone. The natalizumab group had higher magnetization transfer ratio(MTR)volume in normal-appearing brain tissue compared with interferon-treated patients or healthy controls at 1 and 2 years of therapy.

pages.tocTitle: Current and Emerging Therapies: Evidence of Neuroprotection?(E)
pages.cola:
(MTR is often used as a measure of myelin content, but it should be noted that water and edema from inflammation can also affect MTR.)Demyelination was less apparent in MS lesions and normal-appearing brain tissue with natalizumab compared with interferon.62

Explore A Video: A discussion about neuroprotection and repair in MS from ECTRIMS 2012
pages.colb:
Fingolimod

Fingolimod, a sphingosine-1-phosphate receptor modulator, traps lymphocytes in secondary lymph organs, preventing them from migrating into the CNS.63 Fingolimod therefore indirectly prevents T-cell mediated damage to myelin and axons. Fingolimod also interacts with sphingosine-1-phosphate receptors found on various cells throughout the CNS, where it may have direct effects.63 In vitro data suggest that fingolimod63-65:

  • Increases BDNF expression and myelin synthesis
  • Enhances activation, recruitment, and differentiation of OPCs, but may impair their migration
  • Inhibits oligodendrocyte apoptosis
  • Reduces reactive astrogliosis

In cerebellar slice cultures, after demyelination was induced with lysolecithin, administration of fingolimod enhanced remyelination and increased the numbers of nonphagocytic microglia.66

Fingolimod

Fingolimod, a sphingosine-1-phosphate receptor modulator, traps lymphocytes in secondary lymph organs, preventing them from migrating into the CNS.63 Fingolimod therefore indirectly prevents T-cell mediated damage to myelin and axons. Fingolimod also interacts with sphingosine-1-phosphate receptors found on various cells throughout the CNS, where it may have direct effects.63 In vitro data suggest that fingolimod63-65:

  • Increases BDNF expression and myelin synthesis
  • Enhances activation, recruitment, and differentiation of OPCs, but may impair their migration
  • Inhibits oligodendrocyte apoptosis
  • Reduces reactive astrogliosis

In cerebellar slice cultures, after demyelination was induced with lysolecithin, administration of fingolimod enhanced remyelination and increased the numbers of nonphagocytic microglia.66

pages.tocTitle: Current and Emerging Therapies: Evidence of Neuroprotection?(F)
pages.cola:
In a rat EAE model, fingolimod crossed the blood-brain barrier and reached high concentrations in the CNS.67 Its biologically active metabolite was also detected in the CNS, indicating that fingolimod is phosphorylated there.67 In a rat delayed-type hypersensitivity model of MS, fingolimod reduced demyelination as well as a marker of microglial activation compared with controls.68

In the phase III FREEDOMS study, median change in volume of hypointense lesions on T1 imaging was+1.59 with placebo,-0.20 with fingolimod 1.25 mg/day(P=.02 versus placebo), and 0 with fingolimod 0.5 mg/day(P=.01 versus placebo). In the phase III TRANSFORMS trial, mean change in volume of hypointense lesions on T1 imaging was not statistically significant for the fingolimod arms compared with interferon beta-1a. In 2013, Cohen and colleagues69 presented brain volume loss results from three phase III trials of fingolimod(TRANSFORMS, FREEDOMS, and FREEDOMS II). In each of these phase III studies, fingolimod significantly reduced rates of brain atrophy versus comparators(placebo or interferon beta-1a).69
pages.colb:
Explore Figure 2: FREEDOMS Study: Changes in Brain Volume72

In TRANSFORMS, the fingolimod arms had significantly less change from baseline in brain volume compared with the interferon beta-1a arm;differences in brain volume were not accounted for by baseline lesions or new disease activity during first year of treatment.70,71 Brain volume changes from the FREEDOMS trial are shown in Figure 2.72 In FREEDOMS II, fingolimod significantly reduced the rate of brain atrophy compared with placebo over 2 years(-0.86% versus-1.28%).69

Teriflunomide

In a rat EAE model, teriflunomide significantly reduced inflammation, demyelination, and axonal loss, and improved outcomes on somatosensory evoked potential studies.73

In the phase III FREEDOMS study, median change in volume of hypointense lesions on T1 imaging was+1.59 with placebo,-0.20 with fingolimod 1.25 mg/day(P=.02 versus placebo), and 0 with fingolimod 0.5 mg/day(P=.01 versus placebo). In the phase III TRANSFORMS trial, mean change in volume of hypointense lesions on T1 imaging was not statistically significant for the fingolimod arms compared with interferon beta-1a. In 2013, Cohen and colleagues69 presented brain volume loss results from three phase III trials of fingolimod(TRANSFORMS, FREEDOMS, and FREEDOMS II). Explore Figure 2: FREEDOMS Study: Changes in Brain Volume72

In TRANSFORMS, the fingolimod arms had significantly less change from baseline in brain volume compared with the interferon beta-1a arm;differences in brain volume were not accounted for by baseline lesions or new disease activity during first year of treatment.70,71 Brain volume changes from the FREEDOMS trial are shown in Figure 2.72 In FREEDOMS II, fingolimod significantly reduced the rate of brain atrophy compared with placebo over 2 years(-0.86% versus-1.28%).69

Teriflunomide

In a rat EAE model, teriflunomide significantly reduced inflammation, demyelination, and axonal loss, and improved outcomes on somatosensory evoked potential studies.73

pages.tocTitle: Current and Emerging Therapies: Evidence of Neuroprotection?(G)
pages.cola:
In the phase III TEMSO study, 1088 patients with RRMS were randomized to teriflunomide 7 or 14 mg/day or placebo. The average reduction in volume of white matter was significantly less with teriflunomide compared with placebo;however, change in volume of gray matter did not differ between treatment arms.74 Teriflunomide received FDA approval for relapsing forms of MS in September 2012.75(Clinical outcomes of TEMSO are described in Chapter 4.1.)

Dimethyl Fumarate

Dimethyl fumarate and its primary metabolite(monomethyl fumarate)protect astrocytes, oligodendrocytes, and neurons against oxidative stress-related injury and cell death in vitro.76-80 Dimethyl fumarate also downregulates proinflammatory mediators(inducible nitrous oxide synthase, tumor necrosis factor-alpha, interleukin-1 beta, interleukin-6)in vitro, induces type II dendritic cells, and has Nrf2-dependent protective effects against oxidative stress.80-82 Dimethyl fumarate received FDA approval for the treatment of relapsing forms of MS in March 2013.83
pages.colb: Pretreatment of B10.PL mice with dimethyl fumarate protected against AMPA-induced neuronal damage and induced expression of heme oxygenease-1(a molecule induced by Nrf2 in response to oxidative stress)in the brain and spinal cord.84 This suggests some element of neuroprotection, but in a model that is not dependent on inflammation. In a cuprizone model, dimethyl fumarate did not directly protect oligodendrocytes, alter OPC counts, or prevent demyelination, microgliosis, or astrogliosis in the corpus callosum. It may have indirectly helped prevent demyelination by reducing nitric oxide burst in microglia.85 As noted above, the cuprizone model has uncertain relevance to MS pathophysiology. In a phase IIb study, dimethyl fumarate 240 mg three times daily reduced T1-hypointense lesions by 53% after 24 weeks(P=.014).86 More recent studies suggest that dimethyl fumarate reduces axonal transection/degeneration and increases number of myelinated axons in murine cuprizone/rapamycin model.87
pages.page_title: Current and Emerging Therapies: Evidence of Neuroprotection?(G)
pages.template:
In the phase III TEMSO study, 1088 patients with RRMS were randomized to teriflunomide 7 or 14 mg/day or placebo. The average reduction in volume of white matter was significantly less with teriflunomide compared with placebo;however, change in volume of gray matter did not differ between treatment arms.74 Teriflunomide received FDA approval for relapsing forms of MS in September 2012.75(Clinical outcomes of TEMSO are described in Chapter 4.1.)

Dimethyl Fumarate

Dimethyl fumarate and its primary metabolite(monomethyl fumarate)protect astrocytes, oligodendrocytes, and neurons against oxidative stress-related injury and cell death in vitro.76-80 Dimethyl fumarate also downregulates proinflammatory mediators(inducible nitrous oxide synthase, tumor necrosis factor-alpha, interleukin-1 beta, interleukin-6)in vitro, induces type II dendritic cells, and has Nrf2-dependent protective effects against oxidative stress.80-82 Dimethyl fumarate received FDA approval for the treatment of relapsing forms of MS in March 2013.83

Pretreatment of B10.PL mice with dimethyl fumarate protected against AMPA-induced neuronal damage and induced expression of heme oxygenease-1(a molecule induced by Nrf2 in response to oxidative stress)in the brain and spinal cord.84 This suggests some element of neuroprotection, but in a model that is not dependent on inflammation. In a cuprizone model, dimethyl fumarate did not directly protect oligodendrocytes, alter OPC counts, or prevent demyelination, microgliosis, or astrogliosis in the corpus callosum. It may have indirectly helped prevent demyelination by reducing nitric oxide burst in microglia.85 As noted above, the cuprizone model has uncertain relevance to MS pathophysiology. In a phase IIb study, dimethyl fumarate 240 mg three times daily reduced T1-hypointense lesions by 53% after 24 weeks(P=.014).86 More recent studies suggest that dimethyl fumarate reduces axonal transection/degeneration and increases number of myelinated axons in murine cuprizone/rapamycin model.87

pages.tocTitle: Current and Emerging Therapies: Evidence of Neuroprotection?(H)
pages.cola: It also protects against neurotoxic effects of malonate via Nrf2 pathway.88 Further, data from the DEFINE study showed increased brain MTR with dimethyl fumarate, indicating higher myelin content.89
pages.colb:
Investigational Disease-Modifying Therapies for MS

Data are just beginning to emerge on the potential neuroprotective effects of investigational MS disease-modifying therapies.

Laquinimod. Laquinimod increased microglia and macrophage expression of BDNF by three-fold and IGF-1 by 20-fold in vitro.90 In addition, it downregulates astrocyte NF-kappaB activation, reducing inflammation in the CNS, and thereby prevents demyelination, microglial activation, axonal transection, reactive gliosis, and oligodendroglial apoptosis in a cuprizone-induced model of demyelination.91 While laquinimod neither enhanced nor reduced oligodendrocyte progenitor cell viability and proliferation in vitro, it does protect hippocampal cells from oxidative stress and reduce the neurotoxic activity of microglia.92-94
pages.page_title: Current and Emerging Therapies: Evidence of Neuroprotection?(H)
pages.template:
It also protects against neurotoxic effects of malonate via Nrf2 pathway.88 Further, data from the DEFINE study showed increased brain MTR with dimethyl fumarate, indicating higher myelin content.89

 

Investigational Disease-Modifying Therapies for MS

Data are just beginning to emerge on the potential neuroprotective effects of investigational MS disease-modifying therapies.

Laquinimod. Laquinimod increased microglia and macrophage expression of BDNF by three-fold and IGF-1 by 20-fold in vitro.90 In addition, it downregulates astrocyte NF-kappaB activation, reducing inflammation in the CNS, and thereby prevents demyelination, microglial activation, axonal transection, reactive gliosis, and oligodendroglial apoptosis in a cuprizone-induced model of demyelination.91 While laquinimod neither enhanced nor reduced oligodendrocyte progenitor cell viability and proliferation in vitro, it does protect hippocampal cells from oxidative stress and reduce the neurotoxic activity of microglia.92-94

pages.tocTitle: Current and Emerging Therapies: Evidence of Neuroprotection?(I)
pages.cola: In EAE, laquinimod increased BDNF, promoted a CD11b+regulatory cell phenotype, reduced demyelination, and helped preserve axons.95 In a cuprizone murine model, laquinimod prevented demyelination and axonal damage compared with untreated animals, and these protective effects were seen dose dependently.96,97 One caveat is that it is unclear whether cuprizone-induced neurologic damage has relevance to the pathophysiology of MS, and this model may be more appropriate to the study of whether an agent has neuroprotective activity. In mice with EAE, laquinimod increases regulatory T-cells present in the brain, restores BDNF expression to that of healthy control mice, and reduces CNS injury(astrogliosis, demyelination, axonal damage).98 It also restores axon myelination and callosal conduction and protects against cortical and hippocampal damage in EAE.99,100 The application of laquinimod in murine EAE brain slices demonstrates several novel mechanisms of neuroprotection against inflammation-induced synaptic changes.101
pages.colb: In a phase II clinical trial, after 3 months, laquinimod had increased BDNF serum levels 11-fold compared with baseline or placebo.102,103 In the phase III ALLEGRO trial, 1106 patients with RRMS were randomized to laquinimod 0.6 mg/day or placebo. Laquinimod reduced progression of brain atrophy by nearly one third(P <.0001)compared with placebo after 2 years.102 Additional data from ALLEGRO show that laquinimod-treated patients have less white and grey matter loss at month 12 compared with placebo, and that other MRI measures also suggest possible neuroprotective effect.104 Further, not only does laquinimod reduce various imaging markers of irreversible tissue damage(clinical outcomes of ALLEGRO are described in Chapter 4.2)but there is further evidence in MS patients and EAE that laquinimod modulates BDNF and promotes regulatory phenotype of monocytes.105,106
pages.page_title: Current and Emerging Therapies: Evidence of Neuroprotection?(I)
pages.template:
In EAE, laquinimod increased BDNF, promoted a CD11b+regulatory cell phenotype, reduced demyelination, and helped preserve axons.95 In a cuprizone murine model, laquinimod prevented demyelination and axonal damage compared with untreated animals, and these protective effects were seen dose dependently.96,97 One caveat is that it is unclear whether cuprizone-induced neurologic damage has relevance to the pathophysiology of MS, and this model may be more appropriate to the study of whether an agent has neuroprotective activity. In mice with EAE, laquinimod increases regulatory T-cells present in the brain, restores BDNF expression to that of healthy control mice, and reduces CNS injury(astrogliosis, demyelination, axonal damage).98 It also restores axon myelination and callosal conduction and protects against cortical and hippocampal damage in EAE.99,100 The application of laquinimod in murine EAE brain slices demonstrates several novel mechanisms of neuroprotection against inflammation-induced synaptic changes.101

In a phase II clinical trial, after 3 months, laquinimod had increased BDNF serum levels 11-fold compared with baseline or placebo.102,103 In the phase III ALLEGRO trial, 1106 patients with RRMS were randomized to laquinimod 0.6 mg/day or placebo. Laquinimod reduced progression of brain atrophy by nearly one third(P <.0001)compared with placebo after 2 years.102 Additional data from ALLEGRO show that laquinimod-treated patients have less white and grey matter loss at month 12 compared with placebo, and that other MRI measures also suggest possible neuroprotective effect.104 Further, not only does laquinimod reduce various imaging markers of irreversible tissue damage(clinical outcomes of ALLEGRO are described in Chapter 4.2)but there is further evidence in MS patients and EAE that laquinimod modulates BDNF and promotes regulatory phenotype of monocytes.105,106

pages.tocTitle: Current and Emerging Therapies: Evidence of Neuroprotection?(J)
pages.cola:
Daclizumab. Daclizumab reduces brain inflammation by expanding CD56bright natural killer cells, which in turn limit survival of activated T-cells.107

In a phase II study in which daclizumab or placebo was added to interferon, daclizumab did not significantly change the volume of T1 hypointensities from baseline to week 24.108 In another phase II trial of 11 patients with highly active MS that had not responded adequately to interferon, daclizumab did not significantly reduce the volume of black holes from baseline through seven doses of treatment.109 Data from the SELECT trial show daclizumab reduces progression in volume of T1 hypointense lesions(black holes)and T2 hyperintense lesions.110

Alemtuzumab. In peripheral blood mononuclear cell cultures stimulated with myelin basic protein, alemtuzumab increased T-cell expression of BDNF, platelet-derived growth factor, and ciliary neurotrophic factor.111 Media from those cell cultures prolonged the survival of rat neurons, increased the length of axons, and enhanced OPC survival, myelination, and maturation.111
pages.colb:
In the phase II CAMS223 trial, percent change in brain volume was less with alemtuzumab compared with interferon beta-1a 44 micrograms TIW subcutaneously, a trend that became statistically significant during the second year(-0.48 versus-0.86;P=.0024).112 In two phase III trials(CARE-MS I and CARE-MS II), alemtuzumab was found to have adverse effects consistent with earlier phase II studies, including increased risks of secondary autoimmune disorders and infection rates(see chapter 4.2). The drug showed a substantial benefit compared with high-dose interferon in reducing relapse activity in patients with RRMS.113,114

Rituximab, ocrelizumab, and ofatumumab. There is no direct evidence available for neuroprotection with rituximab or ofatumumab. However, there is evidence that B-cells and the antibodies they produce contribute to pathology in spinal cord injury, and mice lacking B-cells show improved locomotor recovery and reduced lesion pathology.115 Thus, B-cell–targeting therapies like rituximab, ocrelizumab, and ofatumumab, should be investigated for neuroprotective potential.

The drug showed a substantial benefit compared with high-dose interferon in reducing relapse activity in patients with RRMS.113,114
